title: Print, "Design for a box of Lefevres util biscuits", ca. 1897
signed: Signed in plate, lower right: Mucha
provenance: Harry C. Sigman; 2013: acquired by Museum
description: Reclining female figure with dark hair, in purple dress, posing in landscape. Ornamental blue frame.
justification: This set of three lithographed panels was one of Alphonse Maria Mucha’s designs for Lefèvre-Utile biscuit packaging.&nbsp; Mucha had a long relationship with Lefèvre-Utile, a French biscuit company founded in Nantes in 1846.&nbsp; Beginning in the 1880s, Lefèvre-Utile commissioned well-known artists to design their packaging and advertising.&nbsp; In 1896, Mucha was commissioned to create posters for the company.&nbsp; He was the first designer to use the company’s initials, LU, as a decorative motif, which he did in his design for the company’s 1897 calendar.&nbsp; The abbreviation proved so popular that the company subsequently formally took up the moniker.&nbsp; Around the turn of the century, Mucha was tasked with designing LU’s packaging designs and a brand identity.&nbsp; Mucha’s designs reflect a particular sensitivity to the shape of the packaging and the pleasant natures of its contents—Mucha’s signature languorous women, along with the use of a consistent font and logo, reinforced LU’s brand identity and transformed the package into its own publicity.&nbsp;&nbsp;

tombstone.epitaph: Print, "Design for a box of Lefevres util biscuits", ca. 1897. Lithograph on paper. Gift of Harry C. Sigman. 2013-21-44.
